newsitem.title: CUBA: Castro says Clinton should be a "statesman".
newsitem.headline: Castro says Clinton should be a "statesman".

text.p: Cuban President Fidel Castro says U.S. President Bill Clinton is influenced in his Cuba policy by electoral considerations and he wishes Clinton would "stop being a candidate and start being a statesman."

Castro, speaking to journalists at a reception at the British Embassy in Havana on Monday night, was asked how he viewed Clinton's prospects for re-election and whether he hoped he might ease Cuba policy if he wins a second term.
Castro said he was not going to predict the result of the November election.
But he added that "perhaps one day he (Clinton) will stop being a candidate and become a statesman".
Castro said he understood that Clinton was currently influenced by electoral concerns.
He did not elaborate, but most Cuban officials believe that Clinton is influenced by the Cuban-American lobby for electoral reasons.
Clinton in March approved a tightening of the longstanding U.S. embargo on Cuba after Cuban jet fighters shot down two small private U.S. planes piloted by Florida-based Cubans.
Castro said he watched Sunday's presidential campaign debate between Clinton and Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole.
"I was bored," he said. "It was a lot of theatre and very little substance."
He reiterated Cuba's view that Washington should sort out affairs at home rather than trying to push Cuba into political change.
"If he (Clinton) wants more democracy in Cuba he should bring more democracy to the United States," Castro said.
